No Date Slated for Pro WJHU Power Boost
WJHU, the former student
operated 10 watt FM radio station of the university, began
broadcasting from AMR II
under the direction of David
Creagh, a professional general
manager on August 18. The
change in station leadership
marks the prelude to a long
awaited power boost to 10,000
watts expected to occur within
the month.
Presently, the professionally
managed station is broacasting
at 10 watts pending final FCC
approval of the power boost at
which time the station will
begin operating from its new
offices at 2216 North Charles.
Originally, the power boost
was to have occurred in .July,
1984, "or soon thereafter," according to University President
Steven Muller in March, 1984.
But after repeated delays lasting

over two years, the station is
only now on the verge of
boosting power.
Most recently, the professionally managed station was to
have gone on the air in June
1986 before its fifth FCC construction permit expired. But
delays hampered that plan.
Then, in July, the station
received word that the FCC had
renewed the broadcast license
of a Frederick, Maryland Christian station owned by Joy, Inc.
which broadcasts on an interfering frequency.
According to Creagh, "It
was a surprise decision to
reinstate the permit of our
Friends in Frederick. Their permit expired and we thought that
that would be the end of it."
He added, "Basically, we had
to start from scratch."
Creagh said that the FCC

gave no reason for its decision
to renew the Frederick station's
license. Joy, Inc. did not even
request the renewal according
to Creagh, but he added that
the FCC is not obliged to
justify its licensing decisions.
In response to the Frederick
licensing, the professionally
managed WJHU applied for a
new FCC construction permit
which it received. The new permit allows the station time to
revamp its planned broadcast
area, decreasing the strength of
the signal sent to the west of
Baltimore (in the direction of
Frederick).
This newest construction permit will expire in eighteen
months, well after Creagh expects the station to be on the
air.

professionally managed station

High Tech Research Center
Planned for Satellite Alley
by John Stempel
Hopkins slates early October
for the groundbreaking of the
proposed" Johns Hopkins
University Montgomery County Center for scientific and
technical graduate research in
Shady Grove, Maryland, subject to this month's approval of
the Montgomery County
Council.
The Planning Board of Montgomery County granted contingent approval August 7 for
the planned site of the center,
which would be located on a
thirty-seven acre tract of land in
the Shady Grove Life Sciences
Center.
The Montgomery Center
would be located near Interstate

270, a corridor nicknamed
"Satellite Alley" because of the
many technological firms
located there.
Last week, Hopkins began
offering courses in computer
science, electrical engineering,
and technical management at
Montgomery College in
Rockville, Maryland. Hopkins
hopes to move the courses to
the Montgomery Center in
March 1988, the completion
date targeted for the center.
"Ultimately," said Edgar
RouMac, assistant provost and
director of the Montgomery
County Center, "Montgomery
County is planning to convey us
funding for the initial teaching
facility, which should have fifteen classrooms, administrative

space, a reading room, and a
small auditorium."
Roulhac said that the initial
county funding for the Montgomery Center would total
over $6 million, and that funding for future development
would be discussed as needs
arise for it.
Other facilities located in the
Shady Grove Center include the
University of Maryland's and
National Bureau of Standards'
Center for Advanced Research
in Biotechnology, the research
facilities of Microbiological
Associates, Inc., and the Otsuka Pharmaceutical Company, the Psychiatric Institute,

2/SEPTEMBER 12, 1986

Downtown Center
Opens in January
by Tom McNamara
Beginning in January, the
School of Continuing Studies
will offer classes at a new
"Downtown Center," with an
expected initial enrollment of
about one thousand credit and
non-credit students. The
Center, located at Charles and
Saratoga Streets, is a part of the
University's effort to better accomodate what Dean of Continuing Studies Stanley C.
Gabor calls "the new majority"
in colleges today—adult, parttime students.
According to Gabor, about
42 percent of all students currently enrolled in colleges and
universities are attending parttime, and about 46 percent are
adults. He said that less than 20
percent of the total number attend full-time and live on campus. Gabor said that because of
changing technology and other
factors, the number of adult
part-time students is growing
and that "the leading universities are reaching out to attract
this market. They are beginning
to see that the adult is also an
important constituency."
There are currently approximately 3300 credit and 3700
non-credit students enrolled in
the School of Continuing

Studies. They are primarily
concentrated at Homewood,
with about 20 percent of the
credit portion at the Columbia
Center, according to Gabor. He
said that the new center could
eventually add 1000 credit and
3000 non-credit to this total,
although these figures are
uncertain; he expects to begin
the spring semester of this
academic year with "not quite
a thousand total" registered
downtown. The courses offered
there will be a subset of those
currently available at the
Homewood campus, but the
program will also include
cultural offerings such as free
concerts and lecture series.
"The School of Continuing
Studies contains the business
division of the University; what
better place to locate business
training and retraining than the
heart of the downtown community?" Gabor said. He explained that both Baltimore
and the University should
benefit from the establishment
of the Center, which is "part of
the University's growing commitment to Baltimore and its
adult community." The new
location will be easily accessible
for 140,000 commuters, and the
school will hold early-morning,
lunchtime, and evening courses

Colombo Promoted
To Dean of Students
by Frank Caiirio
Chris Colombo, who has
served as associate dean of
students for the past three
years, was granted a promotion
on July 1 to dean of students.
This position had been left vacant after an administrative
reshuffling several years ago.
, While Colombo will continue
to report to Homewood Dean
of Administration Robert
Welch, he has taken on additional responsibilities for auxiliary enterprises, which include
supervision of the food service,
university housing, the bank,
and the bookstore. He will remain in charge of student activities, the Hopkins Union,
residential life, the Athletic
Center, ROTC, and the
Chaplain's Office.
Although the process of
evaluating and selecting a food
service contractor was well
underway when Colombo took
on the new post, he was involved in the final stages of the
changeover from ARA.
"Seiler's has been selected as
the new food service after a
careful review of our options.
Our hopes are that they'll be
able to provide excellent service
and food to our population,"
Colombo explained.
"While I haven't tried the
food in the Terrace Room,
they've done several catering
events and I think they've been

very good," he added.
Colombo also announced a
community assistance program
which will begin this year using
Wolman Hall as a model.
"Three undergraduates living
in Wolman will be responsible
for the program. Their duty is
to buld a sense of community
within that apartment building," Colombo explained.
"We want more people to get
to know each other and will try
to promote activities within that
particular group of students,"
added Colombo. "This program will also serve as an information base for those individuals."
To deal more effectively with
the freshmen residing in McCoy
Hall, Colombo explained that
there will be three housemasters
stationed in the building.

Renowned Hopkins BME Prof
Stanley Corrsin Dies of Cancer
by Tom Drohan
Stanley Corrsin, a professor
of biomedical engineering at the
Johns Hopkins University and
reknowned turbulence expert,
died June 2 of cancer.
Corrsin, who was 66, had
taught at Johns Hopkins since
1947, and was named the first
Theophilus Halley Smoot Professor of Engineering in 1981.
Born in Philadelphia, Corrsin graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a
degree in engineering. He attended graduate school at the
California
Institute
of
Technology and received his

doctoral degree there in 1947.
Shortly after receiving his
degree at California, Corrsin
began teaching at Hopkins. It
was here that Corrsin
developed an expertise in the
turbulent flow of liquids and
made significant contributions
to this field and the field of
biomechanics..
Among the many awards
Corrsin received during his
career were election to the National Academy of Engineering, the 1983 American
Physical Society's Fluid
Dynamics Prize and a 1984 induction into the University of
Pennsylvania's Gallery of

Distinguished Engineering
Alumni.
Corrsin also held Sigma Xi's
American Scientist Paper Prize
and the award Docteur Honoris
Causa of the University of
Lyon. Shortly before his death,
Corrsin received the von Karman medal from the American
Society of Civil Engineers, in
recognition of his contributions
to turbulence.
A memorial service will be
held September 30 on the Johns
Hopkins University campus.
Corrsin is survived by his wife
Barbara; a son, Stephen, of
New .York City, and daughter,
Nancy Ashman, of Baltimore.

Hopkins Revokes Recognition of Delta Upsilon
by Frank Caprio
Dean of Administration
Robert S. Welch revealed
earlier this week that the
University has decided to
revoke official recognition of
the Delta Upsilon fraternity.
Contributing to this decision
was "an atmosphere of
tolerance which was allowed"
by brothers at the fraternity
house on the night of the shanty firebombing.
A statement from Welch's
office explained that the
withdrawal of recognition
followed a University investigation into the events immediately preceding the May 24 burning of the anti-apartheid shanty on the lower quad.
The statement continued,
"On the facts before it the
University concluded that the
fraternity as a whole must bear

a degree of responsibility for
these events and their consequences." The withdrawal of
recognition prevents D.U. from
participation in any official
University-sanctioned activities,
including rush, Spring Fair, and
membership in the InterFraternity Council.
D.U. Vice-President Max
Curran told the News-Letter
that the fraternity brothers were
angered and disappointed in the
University's decision, but remain "very enthusiastic" about
their future. "Obviously we
were very upset," continued
Curran. "We didn't feel the
fraternity itself was responsible
for the actions of its individual
members. The incident was not
sanctioned or even discussed at
any D.U. meeting [prior to the
arson]." He added, "We feel
confident that the University
will reinstate us eventually."

"We are still a fraternity,"
asserted Curran. D.U. will continue to receive support from

Orientation Greets
Largest Frosh Class
by A. Al-Shabkhoun
Cutting the number of student advisors by one-third may
seem an odd way to introduce
742 freshmen to Hopkins, but
Orientation '86 "was really successful" according to Orientation Chairman Mary Hiatt.
Indeed, according to Hiatt,
the continued success of Orientation '86 depends on the
unusually small number of student advisors. "The number of
advisors was cut down to get
the most dedicated people only," said Hiatt. A problem that
faces all orientations is that to
"continue the momentum
found during orientation," according to Hiatt. By picking
only those students who seemed most dedicated, this year
Hiatt hopes that the orientation
advisors will develop stronger
and more lasting relationships.
"You can't say that after four
or five days students are
oriented," remarked Hiatt. "It
can be a two or three year process" with advisors facing such
problems as finding off-campus
housing after freshman year.
Hiatt admitted that "certainly there were some disadvantages with the smaller number
of advisors. Having each advisor assigned to five advisees
[instead of the regular three or
four] puts a lot of pressure on
people."
Other changes also contributed to the success of Orientation '86. Among these was
the introduction of team leaders
whose work included helping
the committee chairmen and
assisting with public relations.
A more thorough and interactive advisor training program
including role playing and
group dynamics exercises was
also an aspect of orientation
that Hiatt hopes will continue.
The activities included annual events such as the square
dance and Motown Night and
new activities such as casino
night and a dance held at
Cignels. The Cignels night,
open to freshmen and advisors
of Hopkins, Goucher and
Notre Dame, was so successful
that it was "too crowded" according to Hiatt. "I was shocked by the turn-out. I thought
that the freshmen would be
tired-out by Tuesday," she
continued.
Some events such as the new
wave dance that had been
popular in the past were replaced with fresher ideas."We quit
having the new wave dance
since new wave is out," commented Hiatt, "and we had the
video dance instead."
Having first hand experience
with orientation, Hiatt still
thinks that it can be improved.
"One thing that we need more
of is dorm activities," stated
Hiatt,"we don't need as many
big danLes." She added that,
"Freshmen tend to associate
with those few people that
they've met and feel comfortable with" at large dances instead of meeting new people.

What orientation needs is
"more smaller activities,
although the planning is much
more difficult," she admitted.
Hiatt remarked that problems resulting from dealing
with Hopkins' largest freshman
class were few and minor for
the orientation staff. "It went
pretty well," commented Hiatt,
"It's just that everything costs
more."
Funding for orientation was
not limited to one source,
although the Office of Residential Life did lay-out the vast
majority of the budget. Other
funds were donated by SAC
groups who helped by cosponsoring events. These included
the Kick-Off Dance cosponsored by the Senior Class and
the Black and White Party

Candlelight Vigil Mourns
Jewish Victims of Terrorism
by Marc Spindelman
On the night of September 10
at 8:00 p.m., a group of more
than one hundred students,
faculty, and others gathered in
the Multi-Purpose Room of
AMR 1 to recognize the slaying
of twenty-two Jews in Istanbul,
Turkey, on the night of September 6, and to protest terrorism in general. The terrorist
attack represents the ninth attack directed at Jews outside of
Israel in the last five years.
Diane Cantor, Heinan Landa, and Scott P. Lippe of the
Jewish Students Association
organized the vigil as an "immediate reaction to the
incident."
After meeting for the vigil,

the group lit 6 candles, including twenty-two Yartzeil
candles to mourn the dead
before proceeding to the front
of the library. Hebrew songs
were sung and University
Chaplain Gretchen van Utt
recited the Twenty-Third
Psalm, commonly used at
memorial services. The J.S.A.
requested the psalm because it
is "a source of strength and
faith in the face of pain, hardship, and adversity," said van
Utt.
Rabbi Joseph Katz, of the
Jewish Community Center at
Johns Hopkins University,
spoke at the vigil of how
gratified he was "...that the
younger generation cares. The
sad fact is that life is cheap—

snuffed out quickly and easily.
This makes a community
response, like the one tonight,
all the more important."
Van Utt spoke of the importance of community support by
Christians and Jews alike.
"Terrorism in any form is
unacceptable. We have to join
together and say 'no' to it, and
to all of' its manifestations, as
well as mourning for those who
have died at its murderous
hands."
The candlelight vigil was
sponsored jointly by the Jewish
Students Association, the
Hopkins Jewish League, the
Young Democrats, College
Republicans, and the Office of
the Chaplain at Hopkins.

Frat Gossip Paper Offends
Students and Administrators

(CPS)—Now everyone at
Southern Methodist University
can learn who is sleeping with
whom and who did too much
damage at recent parties,
thanks to a new newspaper called "Greek Times" and an ambitious publisher who hopes to
be covering other college campuses soon.
Greek leaders, in turn, have
complained to the administration that publisher Harry
Shea's revelations are "in poor
taste."
But "things just don't happen in PG," asserts Shea, who
has been circulating his paper,
which appears every three
weeks, on the SMU campus
since last fall.
Shea, who got the idea for
the paper when he attended the
University of Southern California where he worked on a
similar gossip magazine called
"Row Run," believes "a
definite majority (of students)
are in favor of us."
But Janet Watson, president

of SMU's Panhellenic Council,
is a less than avid fan.
"It's really ridiculous when
they report people breaking up
with their boyfriends," she
contends.
Greek Times makes fun of
the Greek system, Watson
maintains, adding the paper
"does not cover the positive
things we do, such as raising
money for scholarship funds."
Administrators are sympathetic to Greek leaders.
"We agree with them,"
maintains Dean of' Student Life
Jim Caswell, adding, "it's not
a very positive paper."
Caswell speculates the school
may challenge Shea's right to
distribute the paper on campus,
but nothing is certain at the moment. "We don't know what
action we will take."
A decision regarding what to
do about the controversial
gossip sheet will be made by
next fall, he adds.
By then, Shea hopes to be
publishing local versions of

Greek Times at the universities
of California at Berkeley and
Los Angeles, Colorado, Texas
at Austin, and Florida.
He published two editions of
a similar paper at Oklahoma
last fall, and although it was
not as successful as SMU's edition, he plans to return to Norman in September.
Other campus officials don't
seem to like such papers, either.
At Florida, for example, the
Beta Theta Pi fraternity in
February 1985 published one
edition of'"Uncensored: The 4
O'Clock Weekly," which
featured racial slurs and a list
of how many beers it would
take to seduce certain UF
women.
Administrators reacted
angrily, and soon suspended
the fraternity.
But Shea's paper is different,
he insists.
"We do not use four-letter
words or publish nude photos,
and we are not malicious,"
Shea says.

Komisky Promises
A 'Solid Council'
by Frank Caprio
"We're not trying to be a big
splashy council this year," Student President Mark Komisky
declared in an interview with
the News-Letter last week.
Komisky discussed a wide range
of important issues facing the
council this semester, including
WJHU radio, housing, fraternities, student services and attempts to improve the council's
general operation.
"My major goal is a much
more solid council, stressing
more communication between
the students and their government. The fact that we have a
totally new council [only five of
last year's members will sit on
council this fall] will also present new challenges."
Since the University decided
to transfer operation of WJHU
from student control to professional management, the limited
opportunities for student participation have stirred up much
protest from undergraduates,
including an ad-hoc council
committee last year. Komisky
believes that the University has
a responsibility to maintain
open channels of communication between the radio management and the students.
"I've attempted to get them
[Provost Richard Longaker and
Vice President for Communications B.J. Norris] to write a letter to all undergraduates on the
status of WJHU past, present,
and future, in hopes that it will
educate students as opposed to
leaving them in the dark as they
have been in the past,"
Komisky explained.
"The administration has also
appointed an advisory board
for WJHU of which I am a
member—the only student
member," Komisky added.
"The advisory board is an attempt to consult more with the
radio station. I would like to see
at least one other student on the
board." The board is composed of about 25 persons, mostly
representatives of the faculty
and administration.
"The Student Council will
undoubtedly examine the recent
proposal for a [student-run]
carrier station," commented
Komisky. Another service being discussed is the creation of
a WJHU stop on the
Homewood-JHMI Shuttle.
"Dean Colombo seemed very
enthusiastic about the idea,"
said Komisky. The offices of
WJHU are located at 2216
North Charles Street.
The council also hopes to be
a participant in the University's
decision-making process concerning student housing and the
fate of the Wolman-McCoy
Apartments. According to
Komisky, University President
Steven Muller has formed a
special committee of the
trustees to examine the housing
problem.
"The University has two
years to act in order to use a
loan it has been granted for
housing improvements," said
Komisky. "The administration
must decide whether to

renovate Wolman and McCoy
or just raze the buildings and
start over. If the decision is
made to rebuild, the council
wants to be sure that students
residing there at that time are
given opportunity to relocate."
In light of recent tensions
between fraternities and the
University administration,
Komisky commented that "the
council would like to find some
way of working with the IFC
[Inter-Fraternity Council]...hut
since the IFC is the student
group with jurisdiction over the
Greeks, the council will probably have a more limited
role."
While last year's council was
generally viewed as "serviceoriented" rather than dealing
effectively with broader issues,
Komisky hopes that his administration will strike a
balance between the two. "I
consider both services and
moral issues equally important.
As a political science major I
have both a realistic approach
and a theoretical interest in
world issues," he explained.
However Komisky is hopeful
for many improvements in student services this school year.
Under the leadership of cochairpersons Heidi Wald and
Janine Unterreiner, the Student
Services Committee will "try to
work out the bugs in programs
which were started last year."
Komisky believes that Wald
and Unterreiner, both former
SSC members, will provide the
experience necessary to continue the programs established
last semester. "I'd like to see
real improvements," he added,
"even if that means fewer
projects."
Komisky would also like to
modify the format of Student
Council meetings in an effort to
increase enthusiasm among the
members and to encourage student attendance.
Student Council meetings are
held every Wednesday at 8 p.m.

The Hoskins News-Letter Policy: A Response

Finishing the Work
Of the Firebombers
Not since the proposed closing of the
Hut two years ago has the campus been
as alive with rumors, gossip and speculation as it is this week.
The issue this time, of course, is South
African divestment and the spark that
has reignited campus-wide interest in the
topic is the trial just completed of three
Hopkins students who alledgedly launched a firebomb attack on a Coalition
for a Free South Africa shanty last May.
While the firebombing and the trial
have captured the limelight of local attention on the subject of South Africa
lately, two new developments of potentially profound significance have occured
that merit serious critical appraisal. Both
developments were initiated by the
University administration and both were
outlined in a curt policy statement which
appeared in the Gazette last week.
The first announcement concerned the
issue of divestment directly. According
to the statement issued by the adminstration, the Executive Committee of the
Board of Trustees has asked the Investment Committee to reconsider its policy
of investing in companies that do
business in South Africa. We applaud
that move.
Last year, we took a strong stand in
favor of divestment arguing that a
university's mission extends beyond
financial well-being. We said at the time
that Hopkins should not profit from investments which support the South
African regime. Instead, we argued,
Hopkins should stand for values—values
which were certainly being violated in
South Africa.
This year, following a summer of everincreasing repression on the part of the
white minority government in South
Africa, we are even more stalwart in our
conviction that Hopkins ought to divest.
The decision to reconsider Hopkins' investment policy, therefore, seems like a
step in the right direction.
In some circles, the move has been
criticized as little more than an attempt
to pass the buck to yet another committee. However, the decision to have the
Investment Committee reconsider
Hopkins' investments seems to be the appropriate starting place for a change in
investment policy. In dealing with matters of such potential financial consequence to the university, it is prudent to
move slowly, carefully, and deliberately. Hopefully, the move to reconsider the
investments will be a prelude to
thoughtful and considered action leading
to complete divestment.
But while we commend the adminstration for its decision to reconsider the
university's investments in South Africa,

we must take exception to the second
policy announced in the Gazette which
would effectively ban the construction of
"unauthorized structures on University
property"—an obvious reference to the
protest shanties and gulag that were
erected on the lower quad at the end of
last semester.
In his commencement address last
May, University President Steven Muller
told graduating members of the university that shanties and gulags are provocative by nature. And, he argued, such
provocation has a proper place in a
university.
Muller was absolutely right.
The nonviolent expression and exchange of ideas not only "has a proper
place" in a university, but is essential to
a healthy learning environment. A
university of all places ought to be a free
forum for the kind of intellectual exchange which characterized the South
African divestment debate and
motivated the construction of the shanties and the gulag.
So, when the Executive Committee announced its decision to ban such
"demonstrations of conviction," as
Muller put it, and arrest those who attempt to display their beliefs in the form
of protest shanties and gulags, the adminstration struck a serious blow to the
very mission of the University. The adminstration may very well have the legal
right to outlaw such structures since the
University is a private institution, but
that right should not be exercised.
In all likelihood, the adminstration's
newly announced shanty-ban was made
with the good intention of preventing the
kind of violence that occured in May.
But banning forms of nonviolent protest
is not the answer. The University's
energies could more profitably be spent
in attempting to change the attitudes of
those who would use force to silence
others. Educational programs similar to
those proposed by the Coalition are a
much wiser alternative to an outright ban
on protest.
Today, on the ninth aniversary of the
death of Steven Biko, the slain South
African Black Consciousness leader, the
University and the Coalition seem headed for a show-down. Plans are underway
to erect a shantytown this afternoon, and
the university adminstration will have to
decide whether or not it will hold fast to
its new policy.
In the end, if the new shanty-ban is enforced, the adminstration may find itself
continuing what the firebombers
started—using force and violence to
silence the opinions of others.

The lead front page story of
the September 2 Gazette contained a statement by University Trustees and the President

construction", presumably
meaning a shantytown.

their jobs.

18/SEPTEMBER 12, 1986

by Elizabeth Harrigan and Jay Lechtman
Well, you didn't go to State U. with twenty friends to down
beers in the college-town bars. For whatever reason, you came
to Hopkins—a small school in a big city. So, you have a map,
and maybe your Student Handbook ...Where do you go from
there? Well, we've come up with a few things to broaden your
Homewood horizons, and keep you from being bored completely between chem tests.

FOOD!!
Everyone's favorite topic—especially when you have eat in the
Terrace Room. Baltimore certainly deserves credit for having some
of the greatest restaurants around (more than would be expected
for a city that spells "deli" with two Ts and a 'y'). Here is a
very partial list of some of our tried-and-true favorites within
walking distance of campus.

.

PJ's: Located in the Charles Apartments, Prs boasts over 100
imported varieties of beer and serves pizza and sandwiches. The
quintessential Hopkins hangout.
Charles Village Pub: 3107 St. Paul; has really great sandwiches
and plays good music.
Homewood Deli: 3105 St. Paul; Reuben lovers, go for it! Also,
if you want a cake for your roomate's birthday or something,
get it here, their bakery is fabulous.
Uncle Lee's: 3317 Greenmount, 366-3333; Uncle Lee's serves
delicious Szechuan food. Try their House Dinners for two or more
(about $10 per person).
Reynolds: 907 W. 36th Street, 243-9202; Rated Best of
Baltimore. Home-cooked Italian and seafood is served in a diner
atmosphere. The best part—it's cheap! Most dinners run about
$5 or less. Only drawback—there's no liquor.
Alonzo's: Cold Spring Lane, 235-3433; This place is more of
a bar than a restaurant, but not too many Hoppies know about
it. Alonzo's serves a fantastic hamburger, and rumor has it that
their pizza is just as good. If you're not up for the walk, get a
ride from the Hopkins security van, it's worth the trip.

20/SEPTEMBER 12, 1986

For those of you with refinement.
Baltimore is not quite the wasteland some make it out to be.
While still suffering under the shadow of Washington, Baltimore
is a rich cultural city in its own right.

Baltimore Museum of Art: Art Museum Drive, 396-7100;
There's no excuse for passing this place up. It is right in our own
backyard, and it's free to everyone 21 and under. Why not kill
an hour or two by checking out the current exhibits—"Textiles
from the Cohn Collection" and "The Spirited Line". The latter
is a collection of the museum's Matisse paintings. The museum
is open Tuesday-Friday, 10-4, Saturday and Sunday, 11-6, and
Thursday evenings, 6-10.
Walters Art Gallery:600 N. Charles, 547-2787; This won't cost
you anything either....it's free to students (bring your ID) and
you can take the Hopkins shuttle to get there. Just ride the shuttle down to the Peabody stop, and walk one block west to Charles
Street—you can't miss it. It's an impressive collection. Beginning September 18th is the exhibit, "The Masters from Titian to
Picasso." The Walters is open Tuesday to Sunday, 11-5.

The Baltimore Museum of Art

Meyerhoff Symphony Hall: Cathedral Street, 783-8110; The
season begins September 18th—a terrific student discount is
available. Show up at the hall one half-hour before the concert
starts, and you can get up to two tickets per ID for $5 each.
There's even a season discount, if you're really into it-35% off
season tickets for selected seats.
Morris A. Mechanic Theater: Hopkins Plaza, 625-4230;
"CATS" is coming!!(but not until March)—however,"Smile"
opens September 30th—call the theater to find out if student rush
tickets will be available for a particular performance.

The Babe Ruth House: 216 Emory Street, 727-1539; George
Herman Ruth was born here in 1895, and his birthplace houses
a museum of Ruth memorabilia, including photographs, wax
Figures, banners, a life-size painting of Ruth, and an audio-visual
show.
Basilica of the Assumption: Cathedral and Mulberry Streets;
[he first Roman Catholic Cathedral in the United States, designed
by Benjamin Latrobe in 1806. The Basilica is designated a National Historical Landmark, and is one of the best examples of
Neo-Classical architecture in the country.
Edgar Allan Poe House: 203 North Amity Street, 675-7973; Poe
lived in this house with his aunt Maria Clemm, and his cousin
(and future bride) Virginia Clemm, from 1832-1835. The building
features daytime and nighttime tours with a candle-light visit to
Poe's grave (not for the weak of heart).
Fort McHenry: East Fort Avenue on Whetstone Point,
962-4290; The "rockets' red glare" over this historic monument
led Francis Scott Key to write "The Star-Spangled Banner" during the War of 1812. The fort is a great place to stroll away a
Saturday afternoon, with an excellent view of the outer Harbor
and the ships coming and going around the downtown piers. Open
S ant 10 pm --admission free.
Greenmount Cemetery: 1400 Greenmount Avenue; Established in 1838, it is one of the oldest public cemeteries in America.
Here you can find the graves of Johns Hopkins and John Wilkes
Booth.

Charm City: 102 Water Street, 576-8558; This club provides
hilarious stand-up comedians from all over. On Fridays, tickets
are $6; shows are at 8:30 and 11:00. Saturdays are $7 with shows
at 7:30, 9:45, and midnight. There is a two-drink minimum per

Charles Theatre: 1711 North Charles, 727-3456; You can always
find something artsy being shown there...not exactly Rambo action. The 1:15 Sunday matinee is only $2, $3.75 all other times.
Mona Lisa with Michael Caine, is showing through September.
Boulevard Theatre: 3302 Greenmount, 235-3707; You'll find
Rambo action here, if you vk -int it.
Rotunda Cinemas land II: Rotunda Mall, 711 W. 40th Street,
235-1800; You can find semi first-run movies here (and they run
for a long time). You can get a weeknight student discount—$2.50
with II). The Rotunda is currently showing Aliens, and Ruthless
People.

Center Stage: 700 N. Calvert, 332-0033; This theatre shows

the performance.
Ethel's Place: 1225 Cathedral St., 727-7077; Located across from
the symphony hall, Ethers provides great jai/ in an elegant, New
York nightclub atmosphere. It's a ten-dollar cover for the show,
but well worth it, Ethel's is a restaurant as well, so you can go
for dinner and enjoy the show afterwards.

Cignels: Lafayette Street, between Charles and St. Paul Streets,
727-1003; If you're looking for a pick-up, don't go to Cignels,
but if you want to dance the night (and morning) away to
some
of the best music in Mobtown, this is the place. The music
and
atmosphere vary depending on the night. (Hopkins senior
Danny Nigrin plays the new stuff.) It's a juice bar, so under-21 is OK.
$7 cover.
Oriole's games: I don't know if you can call this entertainment,
but Memorial stadium is only a 10-15 minute walk from the
dorms. Selected seats are available for student discounts; call
the
stadium at 338-1300.
Photon: North Point Shopping Center; We can't tell you much
about it, because we've never been there. However, it sounds pretty unusual. You get to zap your opponents with a laser pistol.
Photon zaps your wallet, as well: $6.50 for a one-time passport
(whatever that means) and $3.50 for an individual game. They're
open Monday thru Thursday, 4-11 pm, Friday, 4-1 am, Saturday, Noon-1 am, and Sunday, Noon-11 pm. Check out the
coupon somewhere in this issue.

CHARGE!!(All major credit cards accepted)
What the student handbook says about malls (or the lack
thereof) is unfortunately true—they are virtually non-existent in
the city. However, the county malls aren't as far as you might
think. A number of them are within biking distance, and all are
certainly within easy driving distance (if you're lucky enough to
have a car). Some of the closest are:
Mondawmin Mall: 1200 Mondawmin Concourse, 523-1534;
One of the newest; it is just on the other side of Druid Hill Park,
to the west of campus.
Reisterstown Road Plaza:6564 Reisterstown Plaza, 764-3222;
Reisterstown Road north of Northern Parkway.
White Marsh Mall: 8200 Perry Hall Boulevard, 256-0500;
Definitely not close, but huge, and the Office of Residential Life
sponsors a shuttle there about once a month or so.
The Rotunda Mall: 711 W.40th Street; A pseudo-mall at best,
but it has a variety of specialty shops, a smorgasbord, Giant Food
Store, and Rite-Aid Drugs. It's close enough to walk, but a shuttle runs every half-hour, every day during the week, from 8:30
to 11:30 am and 1:15 pm to 4:30 pm—departing from Shriver
Hall.
Owings Mills Mall: This beautiful new mall just opened in
August. Saks Fifth Avenue is the anchor store; the mall also
Bamberger's and Hecht's department stores. Although the department store listing isn't terribly impressive, the mall will certainly
grow quickly. There are many nice shops(and yes, there is a Benetton!) and an upgraded eatery. Just going into the Mall is an event.
It's all done in marble and brass—an elegant atmosphere. The
Metro will have service out to the Owings Mills Mall within the
next few months.

Times are tough in England.
The 13 percent unemployment
rate has forced hordes of young
people to go"on the dole"
(their words for welfare); the
cost of living is going up, and
the quality of life for many
spirals downward. Yet one of
the summer's biggest hits there
is called "Happy Hour," and
whatever irony there is in that
title is obscured by the
relentlessly upbeat melody.

The Housemartins, creators
of "Happy Hour" and a load
of other exuberant tunes, are
representative of a bright trend
in British music—guitar-pop
bands who shun the anger and
anarchy of '70s punk and hardcore, preferring to look back to
the days of '60s innocence and
whimsy (one band even covered
"Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weeny
Yellow Polka Dot Bikini," and
everybody's doing Norman
Greenbaum's hippie-clippy
"Spirit in the Sky"). In London, there's a flourishing live
scene, and three or four dollars
is enough to gain admission to
small clubs like the Timebox,
where there are often several
bands on the night's bill. Many
of them are purveyors of this
Positive Pop sound; Mighty
Mighty, the Close Lobsters,
We've Got A Fuzzbox and
We're Gonna Use It, the Wedding Present, and the Shop
Assistants are some of the best.

Giant on the turntable,

better, and it'shard not to smile.
Robo McGinty has become a

four Woodentops play with

.sent/I hung it on my wall..."
The sincerity in his voice is what
allows him to pull off a lyric

make everything seem charming, not cloying.

Leading the pack, however,
are The Woodentops, who have
There's a lot to love about
proven to have quite a knack this album—the heavenly harfor placing singles at the top of monies in "So Good Today,"
the , U.K. independent-label the shuffling acoustic guitar in

"Last Time," Alice Thompson's refreshingly low-tech
keyboards, and Benny Staple's
amazing array of percussion instruments. Without a false note
or a mediocre song, Giant is the
year's best, happiest, shed-theblues album. Even cynics have
been bowled over by this band.
Try it and see.
The Housemartins find cause
to rejoice from their faith in the
Man Upstairs. "Take Jesus—
Take Marx—Take Hope" is
noted on the inner sleeve of
their debut album, London 0
Hull 4, to be released in the
U.S. next month on Elektra
Records.(A different album title would not be unexpected;
not many Yanks would know
that Hull is the coastal town in
England which is home to the
Housemartins.)
The Housemartins have
recorded several gospel
numbers, but only one, "Lean
On Me," appears here. Uptempo pop with a social conscience
is the order of the day;
"Sheep" attacks conformity,
"Flag Day" is about how the
Royal Family lives in luxury
while many of their subjects
suffer, and "Sitting On A
Fence" takes a shot at apathy.
But the happy-go-lucky
sound of these songs comes
across more strongly than the
brooding lyrics. In most cases,
the tunes are tremendously catchy three-minute bits, even
though "Flag Day" and

P.D. Heaton has an attractive,

he plays a mean harmonica to
boot. Capitalist pigs may not be

London 0 Hull 4 is still a pleasant collection of rousing pop.

George just got out of prison
after seven years and he still has
not learned that Mortwell, his
small-time crime boss, is bad .
news. He asks for a job and is
hired as a chauffeur for
Simone, a low-class prostitute
turned high-class call girl on
whom Mortwell wishes to keep
tabs. With this first job comes
a second: Simone wants George
to find a young friend of hers
whom she left behind on the
local meat rack. She sends
George on the quest through
some of London's more charming tourist attractions Big
Screen Porno 35MM 50p,
where he encounters violence
and degradation of a sort he
had not known existed.
This sordid, depressing little
Film is well-written and
brilliantly acted, but that does
not make it any less sordid or
depressing. Someone as emotionally naive as George is
bound to go through the
wringer when exposed to soemotionally
meone
as
sophisticated as Simone, the
"Mona Lisa" in his rearview
mirror.(How many times does
Nat King Cole have to sing his
song before you get the
message?) Sympathy for the
distant and haughty Simone
grows at first but recedes as she
is revealed to be not just a victim but a victimizer herself. Only when the whole nasty situation almost literally explodes in
George's face does he realize
how he's been used.
Had the movie ended there I
would have come out feeling as
clammy and dirty as George
did. Fortunately, there was an
"upbeat coda," which some
reviewers feels detracts from
the movie's tragic power. I
think, however, that this coda
also gives the film a sharpersense of realism: life does not
end for everyone at the climax
of a tragedy. The survivors
must carry on with their lives,
and George has other problems
he needs to take care of. For
George's sake, I'm glad it had
a "happy" ending: for all he's
a 'bad lot," he tries hard, and
deserves a second chance. The
ending offers no promises, but
it does offer that chance.

but it's fairly smooth. Despite
itself, Ransom addresses important issues. As accompaniment for the advertising age's
other products, it does well
enough. This work is flawed as
are we all.

New 3-D Imaging Comes to Hopkins Hospital
by Joseph Gergyes

Movies of the human body?
That's what physicians at the
Johns Hopkins Hospital have
the benefit of viewing with the
introduction of the PIXAR
computer imaging system. The
PIXAR takes information from
x-rays and quantizes it to form
3-dimensional images which
can be displayed on a monitor
quickly and easily. The
operator of the system can then
manipulate the images—
rotating and magnifying them
as he wishes in a resolution
never before achieved.
The PIXAR system is the
newest instrument radiologists
have in improving their vision
into the world of the human
body. Hopkins is the only
medical center in the world to
have such a system, and only 11
others currently exist
The credit for developing the
PIXAR system does not go to
our Hopkins doctors and
researchers, however, but to the
computer experts at Lucasfilm,
Ltd. The PIXAR was originally developed to produce highly
detailed images for a few of
that company's blockbusters.
"Star Trek II: The Wrath of
Khan," "Return of the Jedi,"
and "Young Sherlock Holmes"
are a few of the movies in which
the PIXAR system can be seen
at work.

The extremely large picture
memory, high speed processors, and easy programmability that allowed the PIXAR to produce the high quality sequences we see in the,
movies led researchers to
believe that it could have fantastic applications to advanced
radiology; Hopkins, therefore,
became the lucky recipient of
one, to determine its value.
Dr. Elliot Fishman, M.D.,
associate professor of radiology
and director of body CT at
Hopkins, is currently looking
into clinical uses of the PIXAR
system and is using it for
multidisciplinary research and
development projects. Orthopedics is one area the PIXAR promises to be of great help
according to Dr. Fishman. "It
will help surgeons see joints,
which is very difficult to visualize using conventional xray pictures." Even more exciting is the possibility of using
the PIXAR system to help
physicians plan surgery.
"With
the PIXAR,"
Fishman notes, "doctors can
see how the bone structure
would look after something is
removed or added." Such a
detailed 3-d picture of the effects of surgery could therefore
help physicians make decisions
on whether to proceed with
surgery. Though this application is "not quite ready," in the
near future surgeons may be

any invasive procedures.
Other applications include
the ability to simulate tumor
growth and regression pattterns
so that oncologists can see
possible changes in a patient's
body before they ever happen.
Prosthetic surgeons can also use
the system to design custom-fit
bone replacements and see how
they would look in a patient's
body.
How does the P1XAR work?
It uses "volumetric rendering

techniques" which means that
not just the surface details of an
object are preserved, but
qualities like thickness. "It
essentially takes slices from a
CT scan, puts the information
on magnetic tape, and then produces images," says Dr.
Fishman.
What makes the PIXAR
system so different from the
other methods of 3-dimension
imaging that have been around
for a few years is that the
system is faster and better. Im-

ages can be formed within 5
minutes of having a CT scan
and they preserve far more subtle images than before possible.
The images can be processed
and viewed in any manner
desired making the PIXAR interactive with the physicians as
well.
Dr. Fishman foresees
widespread use of the PIXAR
in the near future. Probable applications are in the fields of
radiation therapy and diagnosis.

Sex and seizures
J HMI scientists are the first
to have found evidence of a
single
neurochemical
mechanism associated with
both seizure disorders and sexual arousal, a discovery that
ultimately may affect identification and treatment of
epilepsy victims and sexoffenders. The evidence focuses
on the brain's opiate receptors.
James Frost, M.D., Ph.D.,
assistant professor of radiology
and neuroscience found that
some subjects with temporal
lobe epilepsy had increased
opiate receptor activity in the
area of the disturbance.
Laboratory studies have shown
that enkephalins sedate the
brain and lower the threshold
For A seizure. "It may be that
the brain adapts to epilepsy by
increasing the activity of its
own opiate system, creating a.
lesser imbalance between
chemicals that stimulate seizers
and those that suppress them."
The link of opiate receptors
to
sexual
arousal
is
demonstrated using PET
scanning.
Numbers of opiate receptors
present during a resting state
and during arousal were compared. Some of the subjects had
as much as a 40 percent
decrease in vi ible opiate receptors during arousal, which suggests that their brains were producing enkephalins and tying
up the binding sites, leaving

Marrow transplants safer
Scientists at the Johns
Hopkins Oncology Center have
developed a technique that
could make bone marrow
transplantation available for up
to 40 percent more leukemia
patients in some groups. Andrew M. Yeager, M.D.,
pediatrician in charge of the
Hopkins Bone
Marrow
Transplantation program,
reported in the July 17 New
England Journal of Medicine
about the use of' a drug, 4-HC,
that purges hidden cancer cells
from bone marrow. The 4-HC,
purging technique lets patients
who lack suitable donors to use
their own marrow for a bone
marrow transplantation.
By spinning out most—hut
not all—trouble-making lymphocytes from donated bone
marrow
marrow,
bone
transplants may become safer
than ever.
Early results of tests with
lymphocyte removal—called
elutriation—are encouraging,

says Albert D. Donnenberg,
Ph.D., who headed the
team
laboratory
that
transplanted such treated marrow into nine patients.
Bone marrow transplants are
an important part of treatment
for nearly 150 cancer and
aplastic anemia patients at
Hopkins yearly and hundreds
more at other major medical
centers.
Drug and X-ray therapy is effective against these diseases
but will wipe out the normal
blood-producing cells in the
bone marrow when given in
high doses. Therefore, following therapy, many patients are
given a transplant of healthy
marow from a donor, usually a
sibling, to restore blood cell
product ion.
However many patients
develop graft versus host
disease (GVHD), an immune
reaction sparked by proteins on
the patient's cells that trigger
lymphocytes in the graft to attack the patient's own tissues.
Elutriation is one of several
ways under study to reduce the
risk of GVHD by eliminating
most of the graft lymphocytes
able to attack the patient's
tissues.
Ironically, says Donnenberg,
such grafts don't "take" as
easily when all lymphocytes are
removed. In addition, the cells
seem to have an anti-cancer effect, helping prevent recurrence. He finds it best to leave
a few lymphocytes, but not

Efforts among China's
leaders to avoid a Western-style
epidemic of lung cancer and
heart disease led a team of
physicians on an educational
mission to Hang Zhou, the nation's silk capital. The fourman team headed by Thomas
Pearson, M.D., director of
preventive cardiology taught*
some 100 Chinese physicians
about preventive strategies
against cardiovascular diseases
and cancer. Currently, about 60
percent of all Chinese men
smoke. "I think we can make
their physicians aware of smoking as a major risk factor for
heart disease and lung cancer,
and also start them thinking
about transmitting that information to the next generation
of doctors," says Pearson.

Laser-assisted angioplasty
Physicians at the JHM1 have
begun tests with a new laser
technique that
literally
vaporizes fatty clogs into carbon dioxide and water to open
blocked arteries in the leg.
Known as laser-assisted

River blindness drug
A leading cause of blindness
in developing nations—"river
blindness"—can now be
treated with a single pill without
side effects. Known formally as
onchocerciasis, river blindness
is epidemic in central Africa
and central South America. It
is caused by a parasite carried
by blackflies that breed in rivers
and streams. An estimated 40
million people have been infected by the parasite. "We
have shown that Ivermectin, a
complex drug, is a powerful
tool for treating this disease
without the dangerous side effects that other treatments
pose," says Hugh R. Taylor,
M.D. from the Dana Center for
Preventive Opthalmology.
Conventional drugs used to
treat the disease have serious
side effects including damage to
the optic nerve, bleeding within
the retina, quickened heart rate,
and severe headaches.

by Laura Perlinn
After three weeks of practice
and seven scrimmages, the 1986
Johns Hopkins women's field
hockey team opens their season
tomorrow, Saturday, September
13, at Widener University.
They are hoping to continue
their winning streak from last
year that earned them the
championship trophy at the
1985 Baltimore County Field
Hockey Tournament.
The team got off to a good
start early in training camp,
beating American University in
their first scrimmage, 1-0.
Coach Sally Beth Anderson was
especially pleased with her
team's performance, as
American University is a Division 1 school and had beaten
Hopkins 5-0 last year in their
annual scrimmage. A few days
later Hopkins played to the
University of Bath (England)
varsity travelling team.
Hopkins scored first, but Bath
later tied it up and sent the
game into overtime. The Lady
Jays continued last year's trend
of not winning 'extra inning'
games, losing 2-1 in the final
minutes.
The following weekend,
Homewood Field was the site
of the first annual Johns
Hopkins University Round
Robin Tournament with Swarthmore, Lebanon Valley, and
York University. The team lost
to York and Lebanon Valley,
both 1-0, while playing to a
scoreless tie with Swarthmore.
This past week brought two
more scrimmages for the girls.
On Tuesday, the team beat
another Division I school,
Towson State University, 1-0.
Hopkins bested Essex Community College the next day,
3-1.
Although their 'pre-season'
scrimmage record of 3 wins, 3
losses, and 1 tie does not sound
very impressive, Coach Anderson's main objective while
planning the scrimmages is not
necessarily to win. With the
help of assistant coaches Robin
Landry and Harry Marcopolos,
she is trying to iron out as many
kinks as possible in the team's
play before the actual season
begins. After the team's disappointing record in their Round
Robin Tournament, Coach
Anderson sought improvement
by revising the line-up, a major

aspect of the game. The squad
switched from using a 4-3-3 (4
forwards, 3 midfielders, and 3
halfbacks) to a 3-3-3-1 (3 forwards, 3 midfielders, 3
halfbacks, and a sweeper). The
3-3-3-1 set-up appears to be
more defense-oriented than the
4-3-3, but instead the opposite
effect is created. There is more
room in which to work with the
ball and more space for passes.
Another improvement is that
the forwards have better support from the midfielders and
halfbacks. Hopkins is 2-0 using
this strategy, beating two different teams (Towson and
Essex) on different surfaces
(turf and grass).
This year's team has two
great advantages over last year:
strength and depth. There are
11 returning varsity letter winners, a virtual copy of' last
year's starting squad. Coach
Anderson is expecting strong
leadership from Jennifer
Kenoian and April Savoye, this
year's co-captains and last
year's co-scoring leaders. The
depth is provided by the twelve
freshmen, seven of which are
getting playing time with th,
varsity.
The varsity is currently carrying 19 players, including three
goalkeepers (junior Larcia
Premo and freshmen Rachel
McGuckian and Jennie O'Hara).
The rest of the field is comprised of 2 seniors (forward Carol
Butterworth and halfback
Charlotte Seydel), 4 juniors
(forwards Savoye and Kacie
White and midfielders Kenoian
and Heather Klink), 5
sophomores(forward Patty Ordonez, midfielder Alice Collins,
halfbacks Jackie Fatula and
Laura Perlinn, and trusty
sweeper Kathy Hart), and 5
freshmen (forwards Rowena
Tena and Julie Seigrist and
halfbacks Deenie McTear,
Chris Sullivan, and Susan
Steinwald).
The Lady Jays have a busy
program ahead of them, taking
on two or three teams a week.
Their home opener is scheduled for next Tuesday against the
College of Notre Dame at 4:00
p.m. at Homewood Field.
Their next game, on Thursday
at 3:00 p.m., is also at
Homewood, where they will
face Gettysburg, a tough MAC
opponent.

by Steven Silber
Japan, known for adopting
many of America's national
pastimes, may soon be adopting Hopkins' national pastime:
lacrosse. Athletic director and
former lax coach Bob Scott will
arrive in Tokyo on Monday to
begin ten days of clinics at Keio
and Tokyo Universities.
The idea was sprung two
years ago from a conversation
between Hopkins Vice President Ross Jones and Japanese
Prime Minister Yasuhiro
Nakasone, who was here to accept an honorary degree from
the University. Jones had lived
for several years in Japan during the 1950's.
Later, 1956 Hopkins grad
uate Norio Endo would discuss
the idea with sportsmen and
businessmen in Japan interested
in promoting international
understanding through sport.
This summer, Mar Edelson,
on a graduate intern program
with Hopkins, and Tim
Goodell, on a similar program
with the University of Chicago,
spent some time at Tokyo and
Keio Universities teaching the
fundamental of the game to
Japanese athletes. "Marc and

Tim laid the groundwork and
now I'm going over to build on
it," said Coach Scott.
Vice President Jones will join
Scott in Tokyo on Monday
after taking part in the opening
ceremonies of the Hopkins
Nanjing Center for Chinese and
American Studies, near the east
coast of mainland China.

This will not be the first time
that Scott has taught lacrosse to
non-Americans. In 1983 he
traveled to England to work
with 12- and 13-year-olds in
Manchester and London.
"We're going to drop the seed
in Tokyo and let them carry the
load. It will be fun to see what
happens."

Hopkins To Join New League
In an historic agreement,Johns Hopkins University and
seven other small private
schools have formed the
University Athletic Association, a new sports league that
will be "dedicated to the principle that athletic programs
must find their proper place
within the overall academic
mission of each institution."
Joining the Jays in this new
venture will be Carnegie Mellon
in Pittsburgh, Emory in Atlanta, Case Western of Clevelend,
Washington University in St.
Louis, New York University,
the University of Chicago, and
the University of Rochester. It
is believed to be the only league
in the country bound by
philosophy
rather than
geography. Some schools are
nearly 10(X) miles away from
other members.
Clearly, the major stumbling
block is going to be excessive
travel to and from games, thus
1986-87 will be a "transition"
year for everyone involved. In
1987-88 Hopkins will participate in UAA "Festival"
competition in cross-country,
swimming, and fencing. It is
hoped that eventually there will
be regular season competition
in football, soccer, and basketball and yearly tournaments in

eight men's and eight women's
sports. In addition, the five
UAA members with baseball
teams plan to coordinate their
spring trips and meet down in
Honda.
Presently, Hopkins is affil
iated with the Middle Atlantic
Conference in all 23 varsity
sports except football, which is
in the Centennial League, and
lacrosse, which is Hopkins' only Division I sport. According
to Athletic Director Bob Scott,
the new league is not going to
be a replacement for this, but
rather a supplement. In the
words of Dean of Administration Robert S. Welch,"We are
simply taking advantage of an
opportunity to complement our
existing athletic schedules and
offer our students an opportunity to compete with teams
From schools of similar size and

mission in a broader geograph
ical area."
In the long run, the schools
hope that the increased visibility that the league provides will
boost their programs with better athletes and larger fan and
alumni support. All will try to
accomplish this without compromising their academic standards. "The philosophy of the
UAA is based on the concept

Renowned Hopkins BME Prof
Stanley Corrsin Dies of Cancer
by Tom Drohan
Stanley Corrsin, a professor
of biomedical engineering at the
Johns Hopkins University and
reknowned turbulence expert,
died June 2 of cancer.
Corrsin, who was 66, had
taught at Johns Hopkins since
1947, and was named the first
Theophilus Halley Smoot Professor of Engineering in 1981.
Born in Philadelphia, Corrsin graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a
degree in engineering. He attended graduate school at the
California
Institute
of
Technology and received his

doctoral degree there in 1947.
Shortly after receiving his
degree at California, Corrsin
began teaching at Hopkins. It
was here that Corrsin
developed an expertise in the
turbulent flow of liquids and
made significant contributions
to this field and the field of
biomechanics..
Among the many awards
Corrsin received during his
career were election to the National Academy of Engineering, the 1983 American
Physical Society's Fluid
Dynamics Prize and a 1984 induction into the University of
Pennsylvania's Gallery of

Distinguished Engineering
Alumni.
Corrsin also held Sigma Xi's
American Scientist Paper Prize
and the award Docteur Honoris
Causa of the University of
Lyon. Shortly before his death,
Corrsin received the von Karman medal from the American
Society of Civil Engineers, in
recognition of his contributions
to turbulence.
A memorial service will be
held September 30 on the Johns
Hopkins University campus.
Corrsin is survived by his wife
Barbara; a son, Stephen, of
New .York City, and daughter,
Nancy Ashman, of Baltimore.

Hopkins Revokes Recognition of Delta Upsilon
by Frank Caprio
Dean of Administration
Robert S. Welch revealed
earlier this week that the
University has decided to
revoke official recognition of
the Delta Upsilon fraternity.
Contributing to this decision
was "an atmosphere of
tolerance which was allowed"
by brothers at the fraternity
house on the night of the shanty firebombing.
A statement from Welch's
office explained that the
withdrawal of recognition
followed a University investigation into the events immediately preceding the May 24 burning of the anti-apartheid shanty on the lower quad.
The statement continued,
"On the facts before it the
University concluded that the
fraternity as a whole must bear

a degree of responsibility for
these events and their consequences." The withdrawal of
recognition prevents D.U. from
participation in any official
University-sanctioned activities,
including rush, Spring Fair, and
membership in the InterFraternity Council.
D.U. Vice-President Max
Curran told the News-Letter
that the fraternity brothers were
angered and disappointed in the
University's decision, but remain "very enthusiastic" about
their future. "Obviously we
were very upset," continued
Curran. "We didn't feel the
fraternity itself was responsible
for the actions of its individual
members. The incident was not
sanctioned or even discussed at
any D.U. meeting [prior to the
arson]." He added, "We feel
confident that the University
will reinstate us eventually."

"We are still a fraternity,"
asserted Curran. D.U. will continue to receive support from
their alumni corporation, which
owns the D.U. house. Curran
added that a representative of
their international fraternity is
scheduled to meet with the
brothers within the next few
weeks. The international has
agreed to continue to recognize
and support the D.U. chapter.
Although D.U. is no longer
restrained by University policy,
Curran commented,"I am not
sure we're better off. I think the
fraternity would be enhanced
by the guidance of the
University."
Dean of Students Chris Colombo told the News-Letter that
D.U. had submitted an appeal
concerning this matter to Welch
in August. In confirming this,
Welch added that the appeal
was denied.

Orientation Greets
Largest Frosh Class
by A. Al-Shabkhoun
Cutting the number of student advisors by one-third may
seem an odd way to introduce
742 freshmen to Hopkins, but
Orientation '86 "was really successful" according to Orientation Chairman Mary Hiatt.
Indeed, according to Hiatt,
the continued success of Orientation '86 depends on the
unusually small number of student advisors. "The number of
advisors was cut down to get
the most dedicated people only," said Hiatt. A problem that
faces all orientations is that to
"continue the momentum
found during orientation," according to Hiatt. By picking
only those students who seemed most dedicated, this year
Hiatt hopes that the orientation
advisors will develop stronger
and more lasting relationships.
"You can't say that after four
or five days students are
oriented," remarked Hiatt. "It
can be a two or three year process" with advisors facing such
problems as finding off-campus
housing after freshman year.
Hiatt admitted that "certainly there were some disadvantages with the smaller number
of advisors. Having each advisor assigned to five advisees
[instead of the regular three or
four] puts a lot of pressure on
people."
Other changes also contributed to the success of Orientation '86. Among these was
the introduction of team leaders
whose work included helping
the committee chairmen and
assisting with public relations.
A more thorough and interactive advisor training program
including role playing and
group dynamics exercises was
also an aspect of orientation
that Hiatt hopes will continue.
The activities included annual events such as the square
dance and Motown Night and
new activities such as casino
night and a dance held at
Cignels. The Cignels night,
open to freshmen and advisors
of Hopkins, Goucher and
Notre Dame, was so successful
that it was "too crowded" according to Hiatt. "I was shocked by the turn-out. I thought
that the freshmen would be
tired-out by Tuesday," she
continued.
Some events such as the new
wave dance that had been
popular in the past were replaced with fresher ideas."We quit
having the new wave dance
since new wave is out," commented Hiatt, "and we had the
video dance instead."
Having first hand experience
with orientation, Hiatt still
thinks that it can be improved.
"One thing that we need more
of is dorm activities," stated
Hiatt,"we don't need as many
big danLes." She added that,
"Freshmen tend to associate
with those few people that
they've met and feel comfortable with" at large dances instead of meeting new people.

What orientation needs is
"more smaller activities,
although the planning is much
more difficult," she admitted.
Hiatt remarked that problems resulting from dealing
with Hopkins' largest freshman
class were few and minor for
the orientation staff. "It went
pretty well," commented Hiatt,
"It's just that everything costs
more."
Funding for orientation was
not limited to one source,
although the Office of Residential Life did lay-out the vast
majority of the budget. Other
funds were donated by SAC
groups who helped by cosponsoring events. These included
the Kick-Off Dance cosponsored by the Senior Class and
the Black and White Party

Candlelight Vigil Mourns
Jewish Victims of Terrorism
by Marc Spindelman
On the night of September 10
at 8:00 p.m., a group of more
than one hundred students,
faculty, and others gathered in
the Multi-Purpose Room of
AMR 1 to recognize the slaying
of twenty-two Jews in Istanbul,
Turkey, on the night of September 6, and to protest terrorism in general. The terrorist
attack represents the ninth attack directed at Jews outside of
Israel in the last five years.
Diane Cantor, Heinan Landa, and Scott P. Lippe of the
Jewish Students Association
organized the vigil as an "immediate reaction to the
incident."
After meeting for the vigil,

the group lit 6 candles, including twenty-two Yartzeil
candles to mourn the dead
before proceeding to the front
of the library. Hebrew songs
were sung and University
Chaplain Gretchen van Utt
recited the Twenty-Third
Psalm, commonly used at
memorial services. The J.S.A.
requested the psalm because it
is "a source of strength and
faith in the face of pain, hardship, and adversity," said van
Utt.
Rabbi Joseph Katz, of the
Jewish Community Center at
Johns Hopkins University,
spoke at the vigil of how
gratified he was "...that the
younger generation cares. The
sad fact is that life is cheap—

snuffed out quickly and easily.
This makes a community
response, like the one tonight,
all the more important."
Van Utt spoke of the importance of community support by
Christians and Jews alike.
"Terrorism in any form is
unacceptable. We have to join
together and say 'no' to it, and
to all of' its manifestations, as
well as mourning for those who
have died at its murderous
hands."
The candlelight vigil was
sponsored jointly by the Jewish
Students Association, the
Hopkins Jewish League, the
Young Democrats, College
Republicans, and the Office of
the Chaplain at Hopkins.

Frat Gossip Paper Offends
Students and Administrators

(CPS)—Now everyone at
Southern Methodist University
can learn who is sleeping with
whom and who did too much
damage at recent parties,
thanks to a new newspaper called "Greek Times" and an ambitious publisher who hopes to
be covering other college campuses soon.
Greek leaders, in turn, have
complained to the administration that publisher Harry
Shea's revelations are "in poor
taste."
But "things just don't happen in PG," asserts Shea, who
has been circulating his paper,
which appears every three
weeks, on the SMU campus
since last fall.
Shea, who got the idea for
the paper when he attended the
University of Southern California where he worked on a
similar gossip magazine called
"Row Run," believes "a
definite majority (of students)
are in favor of us."
But Janet Watson, president

of SMU's Panhellenic Council,
is a less than avid fan.
"It's really ridiculous when
they report people breaking up
with their boyfriends," she
contends.
Greek Times makes fun of
the Greek system, Watson
maintains, adding the paper
"does not cover the positive
things we do, such as raising
money for scholarship funds."
Administrators are sympathetic to Greek leaders.
"We agree with them,"
maintains Dean of' Student Life
Jim Caswell, adding, "it's not
a very positive paper."
Caswell speculates the school
may challenge Shea's right to
distribute the paper on campus,
but nothing is certain at the moment. "We don't know what
action we will take."
A decision regarding what to
do about the controversial
gossip sheet will be made by
next fall, he adds.
By then, Shea hopes to be
publishing local versions of

Greek Times at the universities
of California at Berkeley and
Los Angeles, Colorado, Texas
at Austin, and Florida.
He published two editions of
a similar paper at Oklahoma
last fall, and although it was
not as successful as SMU's edition, he plans to return to Norman in September.
Other campus officials don't
seem to like such papers, either.
At Florida, for example, the
Beta Theta Pi fraternity in
February 1985 published one
edition of'"Uncensored: The 4
O'Clock Weekly," which
featured racial slurs and a list
of how many beers it would
take to seduce certain UF
women.
Administrators reacted
angrily, and soon suspended
the fraternity.
But Shea's paper is different,
he insists.
"We do not use four-letter
words or publish nude photos,
and we are not malicious,"
Shea says.

Komisky Promises
A 'Solid Council'
by Frank Caprio
"We're not trying to be a big
splashy council this year," Student President Mark Komisky
declared in an interview with
the News-Letter last week.
Komisky discussed a wide range
of important issues facing the
council this semester, including
WJHU radio, housing, fraternities, student services and attempts to improve the council's
general operation.
"My major goal is a much
more solid council, stressing
more communication between
the students and their government. The fact that we have a
totally new council [only five of
last year's members will sit on
council this fall] will also present new challenges."
Since the University decided
to transfer operation of WJHU
from student control to professional management, the limited
opportunities for student participation have stirred up much
protest from undergraduates,
including an ad-hoc council
committee last year. Komisky
believes that the University has
a responsibility to maintain
open channels of communication between the radio management and the students.
"I've attempted to get them
[Provost Richard Longaker and
Vice President for Communications B.J. Norris] to write a letter to all undergraduates on the
status of WJHU past, present,
and future, in hopes that it will
educate students as opposed to
leaving them in the dark as they
have been in the past,"
Komisky explained.
"The administration has also
appointed an advisory board
for WJHU of which I am a
member—the only student
member," Komisky added.
"The advisory board is an attempt to consult more with the
radio station. I would like to see
at least one other student on the
board." The board is composed of about 25 persons, mostly
representatives of the faculty
and administration.
"The Student Council will
undoubtedly examine the recent
proposal for a [student-run]
carrier station," commented
Komisky. Another service being discussed is the creation of
a WJHU stop on the
Homewood-JHMI Shuttle.
"Dean Colombo seemed very
enthusiastic about the idea,"
said Komisky. The offices of
WJHU are located at 2216
North Charles Street.
The council also hopes to be
a participant in the University's
decision-making process concerning student housing and the
fate of the Wolman-McCoy
Apartments. According to
Komisky, University President
Steven Muller has formed a
special committee of the
trustees to examine the housing
problem.
"The University has two
years to act in order to use a
loan it has been granted for
housing improvements," said
Komisky. "The administration
must decide whether to

renovate Wolman and McCoy
or just raze the buildings and
start over. If the decision is
made to rebuild, the council
wants to be sure that students
residing there at that time are
given opportunity to relocate."
In light of recent tensions
between fraternities and the
University administration,
Komisky commented that "the
council would like to find some
way of working with the IFC
[Inter-Fraternity Council]...hut
since the IFC is the student
group with jurisdiction over the
Greeks, the council will probably have a more limited
role."
While last year's council was
generally viewed as "serviceoriented" rather than dealing
effectively with broader issues,
Komisky hopes that his administration will strike a
balance between the two. "I
consider both services and
moral issues equally important.
As a political science major I
have both a realistic approach
and a theoretical interest in
world issues," he explained.
However Komisky is hopeful
for many improvements in student services this school year.
Under the leadership of cochairpersons Heidi Wald and
Janine Unterreiner, the Student
Services Committee will "try to
work out the bugs in programs
which were started last year."
Komisky believes that Wald
and Unterreiner, both former
SSC members, will provide the
experience necessary to continue the programs established
last semester. "I'd like to see
real improvements," he added,
"even if that means fewer
projects."
Komisky would also like to
modify the format of Student
Council meetings in an effort to
increase enthusiasm among the
members and to encourage student attendance.
Student Council meetings are
held every Wednesday at 8 p.m.

JHU's South Africa
The Hoskins News-Letter Policy: A Response

Finishing the Work
Of the Firebombers
Not since the proposed closing of the
Hut two years ago has the campus been
as alive with rumors, gossip and speculation as it is this week.
The issue this time, of course, is South
African divestment and the spark that
has reignited campus-wide interest in the
topic is the trial just completed of three
Hopkins students who alledgedly launched a firebomb attack on a Coalition
for a Free South Africa shanty last May.
While the firebombing and the trial
have captured the limelight of local attention on the subject of South Africa
lately, two new developments of potentially profound significance have occured
that merit serious critical appraisal. Both
developments were initiated by the
University administration and both were
outlined in a curt policy statement which
appeared in the Gazette last week.
The first announcement concerned the
issue of divestment directly. According
to the statement issued by the adminstration, the Executive Committee of the
Board of Trustees has asked the Investment Committee to reconsider its policy
of investing in companies that do
business in South Africa. We applaud
that move.
Last year, we took a strong stand in
favor of divestment arguing that a
university's mission extends beyond
financial well-being. We said at the time
that Hopkins should not profit from investments which support the South
African regime. Instead, we argued,
Hopkins should stand for values—values
which were certainly being violated in
South Africa.
This year, following a summer of everincreasing repression on the part of the
white minority government in South
Africa, we are even more stalwart in our
conviction that Hopkins ought to divest.
The decision to reconsider Hopkins' investment policy, therefore, seems like a
step in the right direction.
In some circles, the move has been
criticized as little more than an attempt
to pass the buck to yet another committee. However, the decision to have the
Investment Committee reconsider
Hopkins' investments seems to be the appropriate starting place for a change in
investment policy. In dealing with matters of such potential financial consequence to the university, it is prudent to
move slowly, carefully, and deliberately. Hopefully, the move to reconsider the
investments will be a prelude to
thoughtful and considered action leading
to complete divestment.
But while we commend the adminstration for its decision to reconsider the
university's investments in South Africa,

we must take exception to the second
policy announced in the Gazette which
would effectively ban the construction of
"unauthorized structures on University
property"—an obvious reference to the
protest shanties and gulag that were
erected on the lower quad at the end of
last semester.
In his commencement address last
May, University President Steven Muller
told graduating members of the university that shanties and gulags are provocative by nature. And, he argued, such
provocation has a proper place in a
university.
Muller was absolutely right.
The nonviolent expression and exchange of ideas not only "has a proper
place" in a university, but is essential to
a healthy learning environment. A
university of all places ought to be a free
forum for the kind of intellectual exchange which characterized the South
African divestment debate and
motivated the construction of the shanties and the gulag.
So, when the Executive Committee announced its decision to ban such
"demonstrations of conviction," as
Muller put it, and arrest those who attempt to display their beliefs in the form
of protest shanties and gulags, the adminstration struck a serious blow to the
very mission of the University. The adminstration may very well have the legal
right to outlaw such structures since the
University is a private institution, but
that right should not be exercised.
In all likelihood, the adminstration's
newly announced shanty-ban was made
with the good intention of preventing the
kind of violence that occured in May.
But banning forms of nonviolent protest
is not the answer. The University's
energies could more profitably be spent
in attempting to change the attitudes of
those who would use force to silence
others. Educational programs similar to
those proposed by the Coalition are a
much wiser alternative to an outright ban
on protest.
Today, on the ninth aniversary of the
death of Steven Biko, the slain South
African Black Consciousness leader, the
University and the Coalition seem headed for a show-down. Plans are underway
to erect a shantytown this afternoon, and
the university adminstration will have to
decide whether or not it will hold fast to
its new policy.
In the end, if the new shanty-ban is enforced, the adminstration may find itself
continuing what the firebombers
started—using force and violence to
silence the opinions of others.

The lead front page story of

South Africa-related investments as well as a prohibition against "unauthorized
construction", presumably
meaning a shantytown.
