To The Editor:
Last Spring, I went through
the trying housemaster application process. When it was all
over, I emerged an alternate.
Andrea Perry, Director of
Residential Life, told the NewsLetter, "Alternates have been
used every year for the last four
years," which led me to believe
that I wasn't completely out of
the running.
Over the summer, due to the
record- breaking size of the
freshman class and the resignation of one of the selected
housemasters, the need to use
alternates arose. Two alternates
and a person who had earlier
been rejected for the position of
housemaster were called in to
fill the vacancies. Offering the
position to a person who had
been rejected earlier when two
alternates were still waiting was
rather irregular.
I had reconsidered my candidacy over the summer, and
had I been asked to step in, I
would have declined the offer.
So why am I writing this letter?
I am writing because I was

bypassed without notification
and for no apparent reason. I
am writing because I don't
want the Office of Residential
Life to make a habit of being
impolite. And, to be perfectly
honest, I am writing because
classes aren't really off to a full
start yet. What the Office of
Residential Life did to me and
the other alternate can readily
be subsumed under the rubrick
of uncivilized.
Most, if not all of the current
housemasters are great and will
do a terrific job, but they were
selected thorugh a magical process that is as unpredictable as
their jobs.
Simran Brara

For those of you with refinement.
Baltimore is not quite the wasteland some make it out to be.
While still suffering under the shadow of Washington, Baltimore
is a rich cultural city in its own right.

Baltimore Museum of Art: Art Museum Drive, 396-7100;
There's no excuse for passing this place up. It is right in our own
backyard, and it's free to everyone 21 and under. Why not kill
an hour or two by checking out the current exhibits—"Textiles
from the Cohn Collection" and "The Spirited Line". The latter
is a collection of the museum's Matisse paintings. The museum
is open Tuesday-Friday, 10-4, Saturday and Sunday, 11-6, and
Thursday evenings, 6-10.
Walters Art Gallery:600 N. Charles, 547-2787; This won't cost
you anything either....it's free to students (bring your ID) and
you can take the Hopkins shuttle to get there. Just ride the shuttle down to the Peabody stop, and walk one block west to Charles
Street—you can't miss it. It's an impressive collection. Beginning September 18th is the exhibit, "The Masters from Titian to
Picasso." The Walters is open Tuesday to Sunday, 11-5.

The Baltimore Museum of Art

Meyerhoff Symphony Hall: Cathedral Street, 783-8110; The
season begins September 18th—a terrific student discount is
available. Show up at the hall one half-hour before the concert
starts, and you can get up to two tickets per ID for $5 each.
There's even a season discount, if you're really into it-35% off
season tickets for selected seats.
Morris A. Mechanic Theater: Hopkins Plaza, 625-4230;
"CATS" is coming!!(but not until March)—however,"Smile"

The Babe Ruth House: 216 Emory Street, 727-1539; George
Herman Ruth was born here in 1895, and his birthplace houses
a museum of Ruth memorabilia, including photographs, wax
Figures, banners, a life-size painting of Ruth, and an audio-visual
show.
Basilica of the Assumption: Cathedral and Mulberry Streets;
[he first Roman Catholic Cathedral in the United States, designed
by Benjamin Latrobe in 1806. The Basilica is designated a National Historical Landmark, and is one of the best examples of
Neo-Classical architecture in the country.
Edgar Allan Poe House: 203 North Amity Street, 675-7973; Poe

Fort McHenry: East Fort Avenue on Whetstone Point,

Saturday afternoon, with an excellent view of the outer Harbor
and the ships coming and going around the downtown piers. Open
S ant 10 pm --admission free.
Greenmount Cemetery: 1400 Greenmount Avenue; Established in 1838, it is one of the oldest public cemeteries in America.

Booth.

What the student handbook says about malls (or the lack

think. A number of them are within biking distance, and all are
certainly within easy driving distance (if you're lucky enough to
have a car). Some of the closest are:

White Marsh Mall: 8200 Perry Hall Boulevard, 256-0500;

sponsors a shuttle there about once a month or so.

but it has a variety of specialty shops, a smorgasbord, Giant Food
Store, and Rite-Aid Drugs. It's close enough to walk, but a shuttle runs every half-hour, every day during the week, from 8:30
to 11:30 am and 1:15 pm to 4:30 pm—departing from Shriver
Hall.
Owings Mills Mall: This beautiful new mall just opened in
August. Saks Fifth Avenue is the anchor store; the mall also
Bamberger's and Hecht's department stores. Although the department store listing isn't terribly impressive, the mall will certainly
grow quickly. There are many nice shops(and yes, there is a Benetton!) and an upgraded eatery. Just going into the Mall is an event.
It's all done in marble and brass—an elegant atmosphere. The
Metro will have service out to the Owings Mills Mall within the
next few months.

whatever irony there is in that
title is obscured by the
relentlessly upbeat melody.

The Housemartins, creators

of other exuberant tunes, are
representative of a bright trend
in British music—guitar-pop
bands who shun the anger and
anarchy of '70s punk and hardcore, preferring to look back to

whimsy (one band even covered
"Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weeny
Yellow Polka Dot Bikini," and
everybody's doing Norman
Greenbaum's hippie-clippy
"Spirit in the Sky"). In London, there's a flourishing live
scene, and three or four dollars
is enough to gain admission to
small clubs like the Timebox,
where there are often several
bands on the night's bill. Many
of them are purveyors of this
Positive Pop sound; Mighty
Mighty, the Close Lobsters,
We've Got A Fuzzbox and
We're Gonna Use It, the Wedding Present, and the Shop
Assistants are some of the best.

New 3-D Imaging Comes to Hopkins Hospital
by Joseph Gergyes

Movies of the human body?
That's what physicians at the
Johns Hopkins Hospital have
the benefit of viewing with the
introduction of the PIXAR
computer imaging system. The
PIXAR takes information from
x-rays and quantizes it to form
3-dimensional images which
can be displayed on a monitor
quickly and easily. The
operator of the system can then
manipulate the images—
rotating and magnifying them
as he wishes in a resolution
never before achieved.
The PIXAR system is the
newest instrument radiologists
have in improving their vision
into the world of the human
body. Hopkins is the only
medical center in the world to
have such a system, and only 11
others currently exist
The credit for developing the
PIXAR system does not go to
our Hopkins doctors and
researchers, however, but to the
computer experts at Lucasfilm,
Ltd. The PIXAR was originally developed to produce highly
detailed images for a few of
that company's blockbusters.
"Star Trek II: The Wrath of
Khan," "Return of the Jedi,"
and "Young Sherlock Holmes"
are a few of the movies in which
the PIXAR system can be seen
at work.

The extremely large picture
memory, high speed processors, and easy programmability that allowed the PIXAR to produce the high quality sequences we see in the,
movies led researchers to
believe that it could have fantastic applications to advanced
radiology; Hopkins, therefore,
became the lucky recipient of
one, to determine its value.
Dr. Elliot Fishman, M.D.,
associate professor of radiology
and director of body CT at
Hopkins, is currently looking
into clinical uses of the PIXAR
system and is using it for
multidisciplinary research and
development projects. Orthopedics is one area the PIXAR promises to be of great help
according to Dr. Fishman. "It
will help surgeons see joints,
which is very difficult to visualize using conventional xray pictures." Even more exciting is the possibility of using
the PIXAR system to help
physicians plan surgery.
"With
the PIXAR,"
Fishman notes, "doctors can
see how the bone structure
would look after something is
removed or added." Such a
detailed 3-d picture of the effects of surgery could therefore
help physicians make decisions
on whether to proceed with
surgery. Though this application is "not quite ready," in the
near future surgeons may be

by Laura Perlinn
After three weeks of practice
and seven scrimmages, the 1986
Johns Hopkins women's field
hockey team opens their season
tomorrow, Saturday, September
13, at Widener University.
They are hoping to continue
their winning streak from last
year that earned them the
championship trophy at the
1985 Baltimore County Field
Hockey Tournament.
The team got off to a good
start early in training camp,
beating American University in
their first scrimmage, 1-0.
Coach Sally Beth Anderson was
especially pleased with her
team's performance, as
American University is a Division 1 school and had beaten
Hopkins 5-0 last year in their
annual scrimmage. A few days
later Hopkins played to the
University of Bath (England)
varsity travelling team.
Hopkins scored first, but Bath
later tied it up and sent the
game into overtime. The Lady
Jays continued last year's trend
of not winning 'extra inning'
games, losing 2-1 in the final
minutes.
The following weekend,
Homewood Field was the site
of the first annual Johns
Hopkins University Round
Robin Tournament with Swarthmore, Lebanon Valley, and
York University. The team lost
to York and Lebanon Valley,
both 1-0, while playing to a
scoreless tie with Swarthmore.
This past week brought two
more scrimmages for the girls.
On Tuesday, the team beat
another Division I school,
Towson State University, 1-0.
Hopkins bested Essex Community College the next day,
3-1.
Although their 'pre-season'
scrimmage record of 3 wins, 3
losses, and 1 tie does not sound
very impressive, Coach Anderson's main objective while
planning the scrimmages is not
necessarily to win. With the
help of assistant coaches Robin
Landry and Harry Marcopolos,
she is trying to iron out as many
kinks as possible in the team's
play before the actual season
begins. After the team's disappointing record in their Round
Robin Tournament, Coach
Anderson sought improvement
by revising the line-up, a major

aspect of the game. The squad
switched from using a 4-3-3 (4
forwards, 3 midfielders, and 3
halfbacks) to a 3-3-3-1 (3 forwards, 3 midfielders, 3
halfbacks, and a sweeper). The
3-3-3-1 set-up appears to be
more defense-oriented than the
4-3-3, but instead the opposite
effect is created. There is more
room in which to work with the
ball and more space for passes.
Another improvement is that
the forwards have better support from the midfielders and
halfbacks. Hopkins is 2-0 using
this strategy, beating two different teams (Towson and
Essex) on different surfaces
(turf and grass).
This year's team has two
great advantages over last year:
strength and depth. There are
11 returning varsity letter winners, a virtual copy of' last
year's starting squad. Coach
Anderson is expecting strong
leadership from Jennifer
Kenoian and April Savoye, this
year's co-captains and last
year's co-scoring leaders. The
depth is provided by the twelve
freshmen, seven of which are
getting playing time with th,
varsity.
The varsity is currently carrying 19 players, including three
goalkeepers (junior Larcia
Premo and freshmen Rachel
McGuckian and Jennie O'Hara).
The rest of the field is comprised of 2 seniors (forward Carol
Butterworth and halfback
Charlotte Seydel), 4 juniors
(forwards Savoye and Kacie
White and midfielders Kenoian
and Heather Klink), 5
sophomores(forward Patty Ordonez, midfielder Alice Collins,
halfbacks Jackie Fatula and
Laura Perlinn, and trusty
sweeper Kathy Hart), and 5
freshmen (forwards Rowena
Tena and Julie Seigrist and
halfbacks Deenie McTear,
Chris Sullivan, and Susan
Steinwald).
The Lady Jays have a busy
program ahead of them, taking
on two or three teams a week.
Their home opener is scheduled for next Tuesday against the
College of Notre Dame at 4:00
p.m. at Homewood Field.
Their next game, on Thursday
at 3:00 p.m., is also at
Homewood, where they will
face Gettysburg, a tough MAC
opponent.

Lacrosse Ready To Invade Japan
by Steven Silber
Japan, known for adopting
many of America's national
pastimes, may soon be adopting Hopkins' national pastime:
lacrosse. Athletic director and
former lax coach Bob Scott will
arrive in Tokyo on Monday to
begin ten days of clinics at Keio
and Tokyo Universities.
The idea was sprung two
years ago from a conversation
between Hopkins Vice President Ross Jones and Japanese
Prime Minister Yasuhiro
Nakasone, who was here to accept an honorary degree from
the University. Jones had lived
for several years in Japan during the 1950's.
Later, 1956 Hopkins grad
uate Norio Endo would discuss
the idea with sportsmen and
businessmen in Japan interested
in promoting international
understanding through sport.
This summer, Mar Edelson,
on a graduate intern program
with Hopkins, and Tim
Goodell, on a similar program
with the University of Chicago,
spent some time at Tokyo and
Keio Universities teaching the
fundamental of the game to
Japanese athletes. "Marc and

Tim laid the groundwork and
now I'm going over to build on
it," said Coach Scott.
Vice President Jones will join
Scott in Tokyo on Monday
after taking part in the opening
ceremonies of the Hopkins
Nanjing Center for Chinese and
American Studies, near the east
coast of mainland China.

This will not be the first time
that Scott has taught lacrosse to
non-Americans. In 1983 he
traveled to England to work
with 12- and 13-year-olds in
Manchester and London.
"We're going to drop the seed
in Tokyo and let them carry the
load. It will be fun to see what
happens."

Hopkins To Join New League
In an historic agreement,Johns Hopkins University and
seven other small private
schools have formed the
University Athletic Association, a new sports league that
will be "dedicated to the principle that athletic programs
must find their proper place
within the overall academic
mission of each institution."
Joining the Jays in this new
venture will be Carnegie Mellon
in Pittsburgh, Emory in Atlanta, Case Western of Clevelend,
Washington University in St.
Louis, New York University,
the University of Chicago, and
the University of Rochester. It
is believed to be the only league
in the country bound by
philosophy
rather than
geography. Some schools are
nearly 10(X) miles away from
other members.
Clearly, the major stumbling
block is going to be excessive
travel to and from games, thus
1986-87 will be a "transition"
year for everyone involved. In
1987-88 Hopkins will participate in UAA "Festival"
competition in cross-country,
swimming, and fencing. It is
hoped that eventually there will
be regular season competition
in football, soccer, and basketball and yearly tournaments in

eight men's and eight women's
sports. In addition, the five
UAA members with baseball
teams plan to coordinate their
spring trips and meet down in
Honda.
Presently, Hopkins is affil
iated with the Middle Atlantic
Conference in all 23 varsity
sports except football, which is
in the Centennial League, and
lacrosse, which is Hopkins' only Division I sport. According
to Athletic Director Bob Scott,
the new league is not going to
be a replacement for this, but
rather a supplement. In the
words of Dean of Administration Robert S. Welch,"We are
simply taking advantage of an
opportunity to complement our
existing athletic schedules and
offer our students an opportunity to compete with teams
From schools of similar size and

mission in a broader geograph
ical area."
In the long run, the schools
hope that the increased visibility that the league provides will
boost their programs with better athletes and larger fan and
alumni support. All will try to
accomplish this without compromising their academic standards. "The philosophy of the
UAA is based on the concept
that student-athletes are
students first and athletes second," says Dr. William Elliot
of Carnegie Mellon. Therefore,
UAA members will admit
athletes under the same standars as everyone else, and
policies regarding financial aid,
academic progress, and student
services will be the same for
athletes as with students in
general.
